Authors:
Qing Ma, Yujuan Du, Nan Chen, Luyi Zhang, Jianhua Li,
Chengxin Fu
Title:
Phylogeography of Davidia involucrata (Davidiaceae) Inferred
from the cpDNA Haplotypes and nSSR Data.
Keywords:
cpDNA, Davidia involucrata, nSSR, phylogeography,
Southwest China.
Abstract:
Davidia involucrata Baill. (Davidiaceae), commonly known
as âChinese dove treeâ is a Tertiary relic deciduous species endemic to
China, and has been listed as an endangered species. Little is known
about the genetic structure, population history and possible Quaternary
refugium area of D. involucrata. However, the population information is
essential for designing efficient conservation strategies to protect the
endangered species from becoming extinct in the wild. Both cpDNA and
nSSR markers showed high genetic diversity within D. involucrata
populations (HS = 0.717; hT = 0.893;pT = 3.14 Ã 10-3). The genetic
divergence of all D. involucrata populations detected in cpDNA (FST =
0.765) was significantly higher than nuclear DNA (FST = 0.239), possibly
reflecting a more important role for pollen dispersal compared to seed.
Results from phylogeographic analyses suggested that the populations of
D. involucrata were divided into Southwest and Central China lineages,
which is consistent with the floristic boundary separating the
Sino-Himalayan and Sino-Japanese Forest subkingdoms. Divergence of the
two lineages was estimated to have occurred around 4.81 Mya during the
Late Miocene/Early Pliocene. Mismatch distribution and neutrality tests
didn’t show significant population growth and range expansion in either
lineage, suggesting the in situ survival of several isolated D.
involucrata populations during the Quaternary glaciation without range
expansion. Our cpDNA data suggested two potential refugia in Southwest
and Central China. Conservation efforts should be directed at
populations in both refugial areas.
